clinicalDescription: Overview: inadequate blood supply to the myocardium (heart muscle). May be asymptomatic or symptomatic Presentation: Asymptomatic, chest pain or shortness of breath or jaw pain or epigastric pain either with exertion or at rest, abnormal ECG, abnormal cardiac catheterization findings of the circulation of the heart. Acute coronary syndrome is always symptomatic and is a a subcategory of coronary artery disease. Hypertension and hyperlipidemia frequently present Assessment: ECG, coronary angiography, stress testing with echocardiogram (pharmacologic or exercise) Plan: Risk reduction (control of hypertension, lipids, weight loss, control of diabetes, exercise), in ACS use of nitrites, beta blockers, supportive care Prognosis: Coronary artery disease can lead to fatal myocardial infarction, damage of the heart muscles causing poor pump function, and abnormal heart rhythms due to lack of adequate blood supply. It is frequently medically managed but if an acute event occurs Prognosis: is best with early intervention (revascularization).
